text: [Music]
I think certain things are different
about each of those Wars but I think
fundamentally both of those wars were
Wars of choice that uh in retrospect
particularly and for me in advance I
believe that Iraq was a bad idea but in
retrospect I think even more people
believe that uh but both of those were
Wars of choice uh one major difference
is the lack of a draft in Iraq versus
the draft in Vietnam I think more people
felt the pain of
Vietnam uh because of the draft and
because so many more people uh across a
broader Spectrum uh of socioeconomic
status were going to the war and so I
think the country felt the
pain and young people particularly felt
the pain uh of Vietnam more than I think
we feel it uh now here in in in 2008
with Iraq because a lot of us don't even
know people that are at War uh we know
of people but there are a lot of us that
don't know people that are in Iraq uh I
meet families on the road and and but I
don't have any family members that uh
are in Iraq and a lot of people don't
and I
think that allows a lot of people to uh
not think about Iraq and not think about
the fact that 4,000 of our soldiers have
died there and and you know tens of
thousands if not hundreds of thousands
of Iraqis have died uh during the time
that we've been there uh it allows us to
kind of distance ourselves from it but I
hope we don't forget that war is costly
War costs a lot of lives it costs a lot
of money that we could have been
spending on a lot of other things and uh
hopefully our next president will not
take us into a war of choice um with the
recklessness that we were taken into
Iraq
